;;7 月 29 日，克里姆林宫发言人德米特里·佩斯科夫在俄罗斯圣彼得堡举行的俄罗斯-非洲峰会后，在俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京举行的新闻发布会上发表讲话，2023。谢尔盖·博比廖夫/塔斯社通过路透社/档案照片主办图片社;
;

;克里姆林宫周一表示，它对以色列和巴勒斯坦领土最近发生的事件极为担忧，并警告说，局势可能会恶化升级为中东更广泛的冲突。

;

;克里姆林宫发言人德米特里·佩斯科夫对记者表示：“我们极为担忧。”

;

;“我们正在密切关注以色列周围发生的事情”

;

;哈马斯武装分子在以色列城镇中肆意横行。周六经历了几十年来最血腥的一天。以色列周日在加沙空袭巴勒斯坦人，据报道双方有数百人死亡。

;

;“我们认为，有必要尽快使局势走上和平道路，因为这种情况的持续下去一轮暴力充满了冲突的进一步升级和扩大，”佩斯科夫说。 “这对该地区来说是一个巨大的危险。”

;

;佩斯科夫表示，俄罗斯大使馆尚无关于有多少在以色列的俄罗斯公民可能在那里受伤或死亡的信息。他还表示，俄罗斯正在与巴勒斯坦人联系，试图了解是否有俄罗斯人在以色列对加沙的袭击中受伤。

;;在这张摄于 2023 年 4 月 11 日的插图中，透过碎玻璃可以看到中国和台湾国旗。 REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo ;
;

;中国周一将对其所谓的台湾贸易壁垒的调查延长了三个月，直至台湾总统选举前夕，促使台北指责北京试图干涉投票.

;

;中国声称拥有自己领土的台湾经常指责北京寻求施加军事或经济压力，以影响其选举结果，以确保有利于中国政府的结果。< /p>;

;中国商务部最初于 4 月份宣布对台湾贸易壁垒展开调查，但现已将调查期限延长至 1 月 12 日，即台湾总统和议会选举前一天。

;< p>;台湾政府贸易谈判办公室表示，延长调查“再次证明中国的所谓贸易调查是出于政治动机，企图以经济胁迫干预我们的选举”。

;

;延长调查该办公室补充说，将日期定为 1 月 12 日，即选举前夕，“凸显了该决定背后的政治动机”。

;

;该办公室表示，这也违反了世界贸易组织的准则，其中台湾和中国都是成员。

;

;“我们多次说过，任何双边贸易问题都应根据世贸组织机制，由双方协商解决。我们也再次呼吁中方重回正轨，不要一再政治操纵贸易问题。”

;

;中国商务部在延期中的简短声明没有详细说明或解释为何做出这样的决定。决定。

;

;台湾此前曾谴责所谓的中国经济胁迫，包括中国对;欧盟成员国允许台北在维尔纽斯开设事实上的大使馆后，立陶宛采取了贸易措施。

;

;中国政府拒绝与台湾总统蔡英文的政府对话英文被指责为分裂分子。她多次提出与中国进行会谈，但表示只有台湾人民才能决定他们的未来。

;

;蔡英文的副手、副总统赖清德是竞选的领跑者根据民意调查，台湾下一任总统。他还提出与中国对话，认为中国也称他为分裂主义者。

;;以色列周一（10 月 9 日）继续袭击加沙，以报复哈马斯武装分子周末的血腥袭击，联合国代表在安理会紧急会议后推动缓和局势并重点保护平民。黛安娜·杜 (Diane To) 报道。;
;

;以色列军队周一仍在奋力清除哈马斯枪手，两天多前，哈马斯枪手从加沙冲过栅栏，造成致命的暴乱，以色列军队表示将在以色列历史上最大规模的动员之后，很快就开始进攻。

;

;以色列境内的几个地点发生了激烈的战斗，在;在一次突袭中杀害了 700 名以色列人;并扣押了数十名人质，粉碎了以色列不可战胜的声誉。

;

;以色列首席军事发言人表示，部队已重新控制了被占领的社区，但由于一些巴勒斯坦枪手仍然活跃，孤立的冲突仍在继续。

;

;“我们现在正在所有社区进行搜查，首席军事发言人丹尼尔·哈加里 (Daniel Hagari) 少将表示：“我们正在清理该地区。”

;

;早些时候，另一位发言人理查德·赫克特 (Richard Hecht) 中校承认，“需要比我们预期更多的时间才能恢复防御状态” ，安全态势”。

;

;数百名以色列平民的尸体遍布城镇街道，在户外迪斯科舞厅被枪杀，并从家中被绑架，这些令人震惊的画面是几十年来从未见过的——旧有的以色列-巴勒斯坦冲突。

;

;以色列已经对加沙地带进行了有史以来最猛烈的轰炸，迄今为止已造成约 500 人死亡，并且可能正在考虑对其放弃近二十年的领土发动前所未有的地面攻击

;

;哈加里说，短短两天内就已经动员了 30 万名预备役军人。

;

;“我们从来没有以如此规模征召过这么多预备役人员，”哈加里说。 “我们正在进攻。”

;

;哈马斯表示，这次袭击是合理的，因为加沙地带在长达 16 年的封锁下陷入困境，而以色列在被占领的约旦河西岸的镇压是多年来最致命的一次，以及谈论吞并巴勒斯坦土地的极右翼以色列政府。以色列和西方国家没有表示任何蓄意大规模屠杀平民的行为是合理的。

;

;暴力行为危及美国支持的以色列和沙特阿拉伯关系正常化的举措 - a ;安全重组;可能会威胁巴勒斯坦人的自决希望，并阻碍哈马斯的支持者伊朗。

;

;军方表示，哈马斯战士继续从加沙越境进入以色列，并补充说，自周六以来，已有 70 至 100 名枪手在贝里地区被杀。

;

;战斗机、直升机连夜炮火袭击了加沙地带的 500 多个哈马斯和伊斯兰圣战组织目标，目标包括哈马斯和伊斯兰圣战组织指挥中心以及哈马斯高级官员鲁希·马什塔的住所。

;

;“加沙地带的代价付出的代价将是非常沉重的，这将改变几代人的现实。”国防部长约阿夫·加兰特在奥法基姆说道。奥法基姆是一个在与哈马斯武装分子的战斗后恢复平静的城镇之一，哈马斯武装分子冲进城镇，杀害平民并劫持人质离开。 .

;

;总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡打击哈马斯的选择可能会因对在袭击中被抓获的许多以色列人的担忧而受到限制。哈马斯控制着狭窄的加沙地带，那里有 230 万巴勒斯坦人的家园。内塔尼亚胡在其长期执政期间一直试图避免的对加沙的全面入侵可能会危及人质的生命。

;

;以色列空军在一份声明中表示，它投放了约 2,000 枚弹药过去20小时内，超过1000吨的炸弹袭击了加沙的8000多个目标。目标包括针对以色列、武装分子活动的一座清真寺以及为武装活动提供服务的 21 座高层建筑的三枚火箭发射器。

;

;自周六以来，至少有 493 人死亡，超过 2,750 人被杀。加沙卫生部表示，“犹太复国主义敌人对加沙妇女儿童居住的房屋、清真寺和学校进行军事袭击和轰炸，构成战争罪和恐怖主义，”哈马斯官员伊扎特·雷希克说以色列退役军事发言人乔纳森·康里克斯中校表示，以色列已征召了大约 10 万名士兵。

;

;“我们的工作是确保在这场战争结束时，哈马斯将不再拥有任何军事能力来威胁以色列平民，除此之外，我们还需要确保哈马斯不会统治加沙地带。”他说。

;

;哈马斯的主要国际盟友伊朗表示祝贺哈马斯参与袭击，但其对联合国的使命 ;否认德黑兰参与了此次行动。除了封锁的加沙之外，以色列军队和伊朗支持的黎巴嫩;真主党民兵< /a>; 周日在埃及交火，两枚;以色列游客;与一名导游一起被枪杀。

;

;世界各地呼吁保持克制，尽管西方国家基本上支持以色列。

;

;以色列的军事，面临;严厉的问题;该国50年来最严重的情报失败，称已重新控制了安全屏障沿线的大多数渗透点，杀死了数百名袭击者并俘获了数十人。

;

;目前加沙周围有数万名士兵以色列军队正在撤离边境周围的以色列人。

;

;以色列尚未公布官方死亡人数，但其媒体称至少 700 人在周六的袭击中丧生，其中包括儿童。军方发言人丹尼尔·哈加里称这是“以色列历史上对无辜平民最严重的屠杀”。内塔尼亚胡发誓要复仇。

;

;巴勒斯坦武装分子将数十名人质劫持到加沙，其中包括士兵和平民、儿童和老人。第二个巴勒斯坦激进组织伊斯兰圣战组织表示，他们扣押了 30 多名俘虏。

;

;周六黎明前，枪手袭击了一场户外舞会，导致数十名年轻人在血腥屠杀中丧生。 。周日，仍有约 30 名党内失踪的以色列人从藏匿处现身。

;

;“残酷的现实是，哈马斯扣押人质是为了防范以色列的报复行动，特别是大规模的地面袭击，并用来交换巴勒斯坦囚犯， “卡内基国际和平基金会高级研究员亚伦·大卫·米勒说道。

;

;美国国防部长劳埃德·奥斯汀表示，他已命令杰拉尔德·R·福特号航母打击群前往地中海东部，以展示对以色列的支持。在加沙，哈马斯发言人哈齐姆·卡西姆谴责美国的声明“实际参与了针对我们人民的侵略”。

;联合国人权办公室周一表示，它担心自莫斯科事件以来没有系统可以遣返被带到俄罗斯的乌克兰儿童乌克兰去年入侵该国，其中一些回来的人报告受到了虐待。

;

;乌克兰当局表示，他们已经识别并核实了近 20,000 名在战争期间被带到俄罗斯的儿童。

;

;到目前为止，乌克兰已遣返了 400 多名儿童，但由于无法进入俄罗斯或南部和东部的大片被占领土，因此不知道到底还有多少儿童。

;

;

;In response, China's ;foreign ministry; urged in a weekend statement the "relevant parties" to remain calm and to end hostilities to protect civilians, adding that "the fundamental way out of the conflict lies in implementing the two-state solution and establishing an independent State of Palestine".

;

;Schumer is leading a rare bipartisan congressional delegation on a trip to Asia, which also includes stops in South Korea and Japan. It aims to advance US economic and national security interests.

;

;"The ongoing events in Israel over the last few days are nothing short of horrific. I urge you and the Chinese people to stand with the Israeli people and condemn the cowardly and vicious attacks," Schumer told Xi during their meeting in Beijing.

;"I say this with respect, but I was disappointed by the foreign minister's statement that showed no sympathy or support for the Israeli people during these troubled times," he added.

;

;Asked about Schumer's remarks, Foreign Ministry spokesperson Mao Ning said at a regular briefing on Monday that China was "highly concerned" about the escalation. "We are very saddened by the civilian casualties caused by the conflict, and also oppose and condemn such acts against civilians," she added.

;Mao said China was calling for a ceasefire to avoid more deaths, and urged Chinese citizens travelling to the area to pay attention to the local security situation and avoid going out.

;;Russian President Vladimir Putin observes exercises held by Russia's strategic nuclear forces, as he takes part in a video link in Moscow, Russia October 26, 2022. Sputnik/Alexei Babushkin/Kremlin via REUTERS/File Photo;
;

;Russia may be paving the way to conduct a nuclear test, a move that would sharply raise tensions with the West and likely prompt other world powers to resume testing for the first time this century.

;

;President Vladimir Putin last week said ;Russia's parliament; should consider ;withdrawing Moscow's ratification; of the 1996 Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT) which prohibits tests involving nuclear explosions. ;Parliamentary leaders; were due to discuss the issue on Monday.

;

;Some Western security analysts now see a growing likelihood of a Russian test, even though Putin said the aim was only to mirror the position of the United States, which has signed but not ratified the treaty.

;

;"A Russian nuclear test is clearly very much on the cards now. I don't think it's a certainty, but it shouldn't surprise anybody if that happens," said James Acton, co-director of the nuclear policy program at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

;

;Matthew Harries, director of proliferation and nuclear policy at the RUSI think-tank in London, said cancelling Russia's ratification would create a "legal and presentational framework for Russia to test if it wants to".

;

;If Moscow did conduct a test, he said, "it would be a strong form of signalling, to put the nuclear threat in people's minds, to try to signal resolve and to evoke fear".

;

;Former Soviet and Russian diplomat Nikolai Sokov went further, saying a Russian nuclear test would mark a very serious escalation towards actually using an atomic weapon.

;

;For that reason, Sokov said, he did not expect Russia to test at this point. Rather, he said, rescinding ratification would be a political step and part of a wider review of Moscow's security obligations to remove perceived imbalances and "level the field" with the United States.

;

;"At the moment I see a nuclear test as unlikely but the situation is very tense and an escalation is not impossible," said Sokov, now senior fellow at the Vienna Center for Disarmament and Non-Proliferation.

;

;He said he could envisage a Russian nuclear test as part of a scenario where the Ukraine war was going very badly for Putin.

;

;"The trick is to get very close to nuclear use but avoid it - to force the adversary to take a step back so the US and NATO think: 'Is it really worth it?' To change the calculation of costs and benefits," Sokov said in a telephone interview.

;

;"At some point you may need to show that you're very, very serious about possibly using nuclear weapons. That's where a nuclear underground test can play a big role."

;

;Sokov said he did not believe that Putin was interested in actually using nuclear weapons, but the risk in such a scenario was that "you simply can lose control of events" and the logic of escalation could lead him to use them even if that was not his intention at the start.

;

;Russia has not conducted a nuclear test since 1990, the year before the collapse of the Soviet Union. It ratified the CTBT in 2000.

;

;Although the treaty has not formally come into force because others including the United States, China, India, Pakistan and Israel have not ratified, it has effectively made nuclear testing taboo. Only North Korea has conducted a test involving a nuclear explosion this century.

;

;Acton said it was plausible, as Sokov said, that Putin was preparing the option of a nuclear test as a warning signal if things went badly for him in Ukraine. But he said it was also possible that Putin had already decided he was going to test, irrespective of what was happening in the war.

;

;In that case, he said, the test would be more a statement about Russia's intention to further develop its nuclear weapons and about their growing importance in its defence posture at a time when its conventional forces have struggled in Ukraine.

;

;Putin last week highlighted two nuclear-capable weapons, the nuclear-propelled ;Burevestnik; cruise missile and the ;Sarmat; intercontinental ballistic missile, which he said Russia would now mass-produce and place on combat duty.

;

;Since the start of his invasion, Putin has served the West with repeated, pointed reminders of Russia's nuclear might, including by announcing the stationing of ;tactical nuclear weapons; in Belarus. He has also suspended Moscow's participation in the ;New START; treaty that limits the number of nuclear warheads that Russia and the United States can deploy.

;

;His comments last week on the CTBT came in direct response to a question by a security analyst, Sergei Karaganov, who suggested to Putin that Russia should ;lower its threshold; for nuclear use in order to "sober up" the West.

;

;Putin said he saw no need to change the doctrine which says Russia may use nuclear weapons in response to a nuclear attack or a threat to the existence of the state. But he was ambivalent on the question of nuclear testing.

;

;"As a rule, experts say, with a new weapon you need to make sure that the special warhead will work without failures and you need to conduct tests," Putin said. He added that he was "not ready to say" whether tests were required.

;

;RUSI's Harries said the next things to watch would be whether Russia would lay further groundwork for a test, perhaps by accusing Washington of preparing one, and whether it continued to support the CTBT by maintaining its share - as the United States and China do - of the global monitoring stations that track test-related seismic activity and radiation.

;

;Acton said that if Russia carried out a test, the United States was likely to follow, and that could prompt China, India and Pakistan could do the same. CNN reported last month that Russia, the United States and China have all built new facilities and dug new tunnels at their nuclear test sites in recent years, according to satellite imagery.

;

;"The more countries test, the more are then likely to test, so I'm pretty concerned about this," Acton said. "If we're in a world in which testing is going on, the first thing that shows us is that nuclear risks have risen."

; Mon, 09 Oct 2023 17:25:04 +0800 Ukraine races to make more war drone components at homehttps://reuters.com/article/ukraine-crisis-drones/ukraine-races-to-make-more-war-drone-components-at-home-idUSKBN3190HD
;;2023-10-09T08:49:48Z;
;

;As Ukraine seeks the upper hand against Russia's far larger military with tens of thousands of cheap attack drones, producers and officials are working to have more components made locally to avoid exposure to shifting geopolitics.

;

;The FPV (first-person-view) drone sector, a ;rapidly expanding; part of Ukraine's defence effort, relies on complex supply lines to get commercially available electronic components, made mostly in China, to Ukrainian startups.

;

;A month ago, Beijing introduced new ;export controls; covering drones and their components. Five Ukrainians involved in the manufacture or supply of FPV drones said they had not yet choked off supplies, but highlighted the need to ramp up local output.

;

;Taras Chmut, head of Ukraine's largest military procurement charity Come Back Alive - which has recently moved into FPV drone procurement - said domestic makers were already making FPV engines, control units, frames and wiring.

;

;But he said the new industry needed to build expertise.

;

;"It's an evolutionary process. You cannot simultaneously localize everything in Ukraine. Some things you may never be able to localize."

;

;FPV drones - fast, nimble and difficult to pilot - began to be used as a cost-effective way to strike targets after Russia invaded Ukraine in February 2022.

;

;Their deployment on both sides of the war has skyrocketed this year, and footage of FPVs costing less than $1,000 damaging multi-million dollar targets like tanks and air defence systems abounds online in videos Reuters has not been able to verify.

;

;Mykhailo Fedorov, digital transformation minister and a champion of the drone sector throughout the war, told Reuters that switching to domestic manufacturing of components was a slow but necessary process.

;

;"I think we can do this in several years, and that this needs to happen so that we can scale up more quickly in our own production," he said.

;

;Fedorov estimated the number of drones at the front, an ever-fluctuating figure, to be in the tens of thousands, and said most of those were FPVs.

;

;In just three days in August, Ukrainian military aid foundation Come Back Alive, alongside state-backed fundraising platform United24, raised $6.4 million for 10,000 FPV drones.

;

;However, Chmut said that the potential for FPV use on the frontline was not being fully maximised because of supply disruptions and lack of funding for faster production.

;

;"Right now ... there are more FPV pilots than (the) capacity to provide them with machines and weaponry."

;

;China, which has ;denied; Western ;allegations; its companies have helped Iran supply Russia with drones, cited a desire to help maintain world peace in its announcement of the new ;export controls; from Sept. 1.

;

;Its commerce ministry did not respond to a request for comment on fears expressed by Ukrainians that the curbs were designed to limit their access to drones for use in the war.

;

;Four Ukrainian drone makers and suppliers told Reuters the vast majority of commercially available parts for FPV drones were sourced from China.

;

;"It's a lot. But there are other countries apart from China, and Ukraine is actively working to swap out components for domestic ones," said Chmut.

;

;Parts are often bought in small batches on e-commerce platforms, but larger orders need agreements with producers.

;

;Two makers told Reuters they used intermediary companies in other countries when ordering from China so that no mention of Ukraine appears on purchase and shipping documents - as makers appear scared to sell to Ukraine.

;

;An FPV pilot said when he buys parts on Chinese online platforms to make FPVs for his own use, he cannot be sure that they will still be available a month later.

;

;This slows the process down, as every time parts are changed the drone has to be re-tested.
